content.question: In experiment <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, a disk of mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and radius <math alttext="R sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> rotates about a center axle, as shown in the figure. An object of mass <math alttext="lowercase m sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> hangs from a string that is wound around the disk. The object is released from rest and falls a vertical distance <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> before striking the ground. The string does not completely unwind. The disk’s angular momentum is <math alttext="L sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> when the falling object strikes the ground. The rotational inertia of the disk is <math alttext="I sub d equals the fraction uppercase M R squared over 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>M</mi><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. In experiment <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, a thin circular hoop with mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and radius <math alttext="R sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> replaces the disk, and the experiment is repeated. The rotational inertia of the hoop is <math alttext="I sub h equals uppercase M R squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>M</mi><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. How does the magnitude of the hoop’s final angular momentum compare to the magnitude of the disk’s final angular momentum?

choices.label: The hoop’s final angular momentum is less than the disk’s final angular momentum.
The hoop’s final angular momentum is equal to the disk’s final angular momentum.
The hoop’s final angular momentum is greater than the disk’s final angular momentum.
The comparison cannot be made without knowing the net torque exerted on the disk and the hoop.

content.answer: The hoop’s final angular momentum is greater than the disk’s final angular momentum.
